US Market Wrap - 13 July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, crude up, Dollar Index flat
  • REAR-VIEW: Trump/May meeting, WFC, PNC, JPM and C mixed earnings, US University of Michigan Sentiment miss, BoE's Cunliffe
  • COMING-UP NEXT WEEK: Trump/Putin Summit, US Retail Sales, RBA Minutes, UK Labour Market, Fed Chair Powell’s Semi-Annual, UK CPI, EZ CPI (Final), US Housing Starts & Building Permits, Australian Labour Market, UK Retail Sales, Japanese CPI, Canadian CPI.

 

* TRUMP/MAY MEETING: The meeting between UK PM May and US President Trump stroke a surprising positive note just hours after a report was published by The Sun in which the US President criticised UK PM May’s Brexit plan, claiming it would ruin the trade ties between the two countries. At the conference Trump dismissed the criticism calling the news as fake and showed a much more positive stance on the US ties with the UK; he stated ‘whatever’ the UK decided  to do after Brexit is fine with him and defined the relationship between the two countries "the highest level of special". Trump also touched on geopolitics, appearing hopeful for a good relationship with Russia whilst he reiterated the horrible trade relationship with the EU will change. UK PM May’s focus was on Brexit, she confirmed the UK will leave the EU on the set date and the nation will pursue an ambitious UK/US trade deal.

* FED: The Fed's Monetary Policy report reiterated the Fed’s case for gradual rate hikes 'consistent with a sustained expansion' and noted that, on balance, the economic activity in the US appears to have expanded at a solid pace in the first half of 2018 noting valuations are 'elevated' for some assets. Fed’s Kaplan stated that he only expects one more rate hike this year but could be convinced of a fourth depending on how the outlook evolves.

* BOE: BoE's Cunliffe noted a significant drop of activity in the UK was driven by poor weather and added it is likely the economy is expanding around or its potential growth rate.

* SPX +0.1% at 2801.20, NDX +0.1% at 7375.8, DJI +0.4% at 25018. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.6%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.3%, Energy: +0.56%, Financials: -0.5%, Health Care: +0.2%, Industrials: +0.6%, Materials: 0.0%, Telecoms: -0.8%, Tech: 0.0%, Utilities: +0.1%.

The SPX hit a five-month high in early trade with the DJI breaking above 25,000 for the first time in over a month before paring back later in the session.  

* EARNINGS: Major US banks officially kicked off earnings season after reporting mixed numbers. Wells Fargo (WFC) fell 2% as it showed a bigger than forecasted drop in its quarterly profits due to slower lending and higher costs. Citigroup (C ) posted similar losses on the back of lower debt underwriting. On the flip side, JP Morgan (JPM) and PNC Financial (PNC) held in positive territory after reporting a beat on both top and bottom line. The results overall dragged the financial sector in the red.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: AT&T (T) posted losses of 2% and weighed on the telecom sector on the news that the US DoJ launched an appeal on Friday against the USD 80bln merger of AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) after the deal won approval in June by a Judge who did not impose any conditions. Elsewhere, major retailers namely Ulta Beauty, Best Buy and Lowe’s outperformed in the index and lifted the consumer non-cyclicals. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) was at the bottom of the DJI after being charged USD 4.69bln in damages in a lawsuit filed by women claiming some of its products containing asbestos caused cancer.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 6+ TICKS HIGHER AT 120.11+.

Treasuries held in positive ground on Friday amid decent volume on the buy side heading into the weekend and supported by marginal flow factors coming from Europe and Japan. Most of the action was concentrated in the belly of the curve where yields were lower by c.2bps. Spread were mixed as 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c.1bps whilst 5s30s widened by c.1bps.

* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (Q8) SETTLE 68C HIGHER AT $71.01; BRENT (U8) SETTLES 88c HIGHER AT $75.33.

Oil drifted higher on Friday, on no major fundamentals, with prices supported by strike action continuing in Norway and by Russia reporting a lower than agreed oil production in June, touted by Russian Energy Minister Novak to be 120k bpd below the OPEC+ set level. The oil complex overall ended the second consecutive week lower amid easing supply in Libya, where major ports have reopened, and on the possibility Iran could still export some of its oil, though the French request for Iranian sanction waiver was rejected by the US on Friday. A decline of the highs was seen late in the session on reports that the Trump administration could tap the SPR to keep gasoline prices lower ahead of the mid-term elections. 

US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (13 Jul) 863 (Prev. 863)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (13 Jul) 1054 (Prev. 1052)

US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (13 Jul) 189 (Prev. 187)

* WEEKLY FX WRAP:

* DXY: Back on the 95.000 handle and on course to end the week stronger than it was before last Friday’s US jobs data that sparked a broad Dollar sell-off. Firmer than expected inflation, ramped up US-China trade threats, a volatile, but ultimately renegotiated NATO deal and the demise of rival currencies has all combined to push the index back up, and not far from best levels seen so far in 2018 (95.531 at the end of June).

* NZD: Ending the week as worst G10 performer, but not necessarily the biggest loser overall, with a disappointing NZ manufacturing PMI adding to more general global tariff/protectionism tensions. The Kiwi is currently just under 0.6750 vs the Usd and considerably closer to circa 0.6725 lows than 0.6850+ peaks on Monday.

* CHF: Another big net loser vs the Usd, and Eur, with the Franc back below parity and down to fresh ytd lows near 1.0070, while the cross has hit 1.1700 after stops were tripped on a break of 1.1660. No real independent props for the Chf having traded as high as 0.9855 vs the Usd on Monday.

* GBP: A bad week for the Pound, largely on Brexit factors and more UK political instability after last Friday’s cabinet summit at Chequers to formulate a White Paper. The perceived ‘soft’ plan for a future relationship with the EU prompted more divisions within the Tory party and led to the resignations of Brexit Minister Davis and Foreign Secretary Johnson, while Cable tumbled from circa 1.3360 at the start of the week to effectively 1.3100 earlier today. Back up near 1.3175 now (where stops were triggered incidentally on the way down) after a joint press conference from UK PM May and US President Trump went a long, if not all the way towards denouncing reports that a soft Brexit would scotch any chance of a US-UK trade agreement (attributed to Trump).

* EUR: Aside from the aforementioned Greenback revival, the single currency was undermined by a mixture of dovish-leaning ECB minutes (emphasizing the open-ended nature of QE and rate guidance in stark contrast to sources suggesting some GC members prefer tightening in July 2019 vs at least through Summer), re-positioning and bearish technicals – Eur/Usd down to 1.1610 vs 1.1790 at best before paring some losses into a decent (1.2 bn) option expiry at the 1.1650 strike at the NY cut.

* JPY: Perhaps the underperforming over the week on balance, and like the Eur partly on negative CB impulses, as sources claim that the BoJ may downgrade its inflation outlook again at the end of July policy meeting, to only reach target in 3 years. Usd/Jpy also saw stop-driven flows on the way up to almost 112.80 from 110.30 at the start of the week, as recent multi-peaks were cleared, major fibs and other chart resistance levels were breached.

* CAD: The Loonie has endured a very volatile 2nd half, with a decent rally in wake of the BoC rate hike on Wednesday completely wiped out and more by the end of the day as oil prices plunged. Back to the policy meeting, a 25 bp tightening was almost unanimously anticipated and priced in, but the accompanying statement was upbeat overall as guidance was for more, albeit gradual and data pending, hikes, and factoring in headwinds caused by US-Canadian reciprocal import tariffs. Usd/Cad range for the week, 1.3220 (Thursday) to 1.3060 (Wednesday), and circa 1.3170 at present.

AUD/YUAN: Buffeted by global trade winds and the heightened US vs China tariff threat (up to $200 bn goods now being lined up for a 10% tax by the former, on top of the initial $34 bn already imposed and further $16 bn pending). The Aud failed several times ahead of 0.7500 vs the Usd and recoiled to a fresh 2018 low circa 0.7360 yesterday before recovering some composure due to no direct retaliation from Beijing, thus far. However, as the Cny and Cnh both weaken sharply, some are of the opinion that China is deploying other measures (weapons), with the former being fixed by the PBoc and off-shore Yuan down below levels (4.7000+) that previously prompted intervention (both verbally and actively via local banks).

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 13th July 2018 - Earnings from JPM, PNC, C, WFC
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

13th July 2018

Earnings

  • JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) Q2 EPS USD 2.29 vs. Exp. USD 2.22, revenue USD 27.8bln vs. Exp. USD 27.36bln. Investment banking revenue of USD 1.95bln. Equity markets revenue USD 2.0bln, up 24% on Prev. FICC sales and trading revenue USD 3.45bln vs. Exp. USD 3.20bln. Quarterly fixed income markets revenue of USD 3.5bln. (Newswires)
  • PNC Financial Services Group Inc (PNC) Q2 EPS USD 2.72 vs. Exp. USD 2.58, revenue USD 4.3bln vs. Exp. USD 4.26bln. (Newswires) 
  • Citigroup Inc (C) Q2 EPS USD 1.63 vs. Exp. USD 1.57, revenue USD 18.47bln vs. Exp. USD 18.16bln. Q2 Fixed Income Markets revenue USD 3.03bln vs. Exp. USD 3.16bln. Reports Q2 Tier 1 Capital Ratio 12.1%. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) Q2 EPS USD 0.98 vs. Exp. USD 1.12, revenue USD 21.6bln vs. Exp. USD 21.71bln. Net interest income USD 12.5bln, Q2 noninterest expense USD 14bln and allowance for credit losses USD 11.1bln. (Newswires)
  • First Republic (FRC) Q2 EPS USD 1.20 vs. Exp. USD 1.17, revenue USD 0.744bln vs. Exp USD 0.757bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant announces a new USD 300mln clean energy fund in China aimed at connecting suppliers through renewable energy. Separately, LG Display (LPL KS) entered an agreement with the co. for the shipment of OLED panels for the new iPhone generation set to launch in H2 2018.  (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The healthcare group is to pay USD 4.69bln in damages (4.14bln in punitive damages and USD 550mln in compensatory damages) after a Missouri jury found the co. responsible in a lawsuit filed by 22 women who claimed talc products containing asbestos caused ovarian cancer. (Newswires)
  • McDonalds (MCD) – The investigation conducted by the llinois Department of Public Health confirmed 90 cases of cyclosporiasis liked with its salads. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – The co. appointed Cathleen Benko to the board of directors. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The co. announces it is undecided on whether to sell Seiyu, after Nikkei this week reported that the supermarket was looking to sell the Japanese unit for USD 4.5bln. (Newswires)  
  • Walt Disney (DIS) – UK regulators warned that the co. must pay at least GBP 14/shr (USD 32.5bln) to successfully acquire assets in Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), following the USD 34bln offer from Comcast (CMCSA). (Newswires)

S&P500

  • 500mln+ market caps (XRX, NWL, GE, VRX, PF) – Activist investors announced campaigns targeting 136 companies with market values above 550mln for a USD 40bln spending; according to a study by Lazard. (WSJ)
  • Amgen (AMGN) – The co. and UCB announced it has re-submit the Biologics License Application to the FDA for Evenity, an antibody drug for the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. (Newswires)
  • AT&T (T)/Time Warner (TWX) – The US DOJ has filed to appeal against the USD 80bln merger of AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) after the deal won approval in June by a Judge who did not impose any conditions on the merger; the DOJ has alleged that the deal would decrease competition and raise prices for consumers. AT&T said it was surprised by the decision, and its CEO said the chance of losing the DOJ appeal was remote and ‘changes nothing’, adding that the decision may also impact the Fox/Comcast/Disney deal (FOXA/CMCSA/DIS). (CNBC)
  • Fluor (FLR) - Fluor Marine Propulsion was awarded a USD 1.22bln contract by the US Navy for naval nuclear propulsion work at the Naval Nuclear Laboratory. (Newswires)
  • Harley-Davidson (HOG) – The motorcycle maker was asked to open a factory in Berlin, Germany, according to a report published in Germany. (Newswires)
  • Kellogg (K) – Honey Smacks cereals that were recalled last month over possible salmonella contamination, are still being sold at some retail outlets, according to the FDA; the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended consumers not eat the cereal and retailers not sell any Kellogg's Honey Smacks cereal due to the risks of salmonella. (Newswires)
  • Northrop Grumman (NOC) - CEO Wes Bush is to resign in 2019. (Newswires)
  • Parker Hannifin (PH) – The co.’s unit Parker Aerospace signed a five-year master distributor agreement with Aviall for its product line. (Newswires)
  • Target (TGT) - The co. is planning to offer a one-day online sale on June 17th which overlaps with Amazon's (AMZN) Prime Day. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – Top users have lost around 2% followers after the social media introduced policy to suspend accounts over fraud suspicion. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Broadcom (AVGO) – The tech co. is shifting its interest towards infrastructure software groups rather than chipmakers, after it failed to acquire Qualcomm (QCOM) and after the announcement of its acquisition of CA Technologies (CA) for around USD 19bln, according to people familiar with the matter. (CNBC)
  • Comcast (CMCSA) – Sky (SKY LN) is anticipated to receive more bids from the co. and 21st Century Fox (FOXA), after Comcast increased its offer from GBP 14.00/shr to GBP 14.75/shr. (FT)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media reports that 115mln users in Indonesia were not affected by the data breach in relation with Cambridge Analytica. Separately, heads of News Feed struggled to explain why InfoWars, a profile that provides conspiracy theories, is allowed to keep its page. (CNN)
  • Intel (INTC)/HP (HPQ) – Gartner (IT) reports total Q2 PC shipments of 62.1mln units, up 1.4% from one year ago. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Apollo (APO) – The co. and founder Leon Black were sued by Cadera for USD 1.5bln over an insurance firm bidding war. (FT)
  • Bruker (BRKR) – The co. acquires JPK Instruments; undisclosed terms. (Newswires)
  • Copa Holdings (CPA) – The co. reports June system-wide passenger traffic (RPM) up 10.9% y/y and capacity (ASM) up 8.2%. (Newswires)
  • IGT (IGT) – The co. expands its deal for the provision of INTELLIGEN to Louisiana's video gaming programme for an additional 9.5 years. (Newswires)
  • Immunomedics (IMMU) – The co. is in talks with Italy's BSP Pharmaceuticals to acquire sacituzumab govitecan, an antibody drug. (Newswires)
  • Ingredion (INGR) – The co. lowers its Q2 Adj. EPS to USD 1.63 – USD 1.68 from consensus USD 1.92. Lowers FY18 EPS view to USD 7.50 – USD 7.80 from USD 7.90 – USD 8.20. (Newswires)
  • Insulet (PODD) – The co. expands its diabetes data partnership with Glooko in Europe. (Newswires)
  • Mammoth Energy (TUSK)/Gulfport Energy (GPOR) – The two oil groups extend their partnership for pressure pumping services up to December 2021. (Newswires)
  • MasterCard (MA) – The credit card issuer has apologised following an outage that blocked customers’ payments globally. (FT)
  • Terex (TEX) – The co. announced a authorises a new USD 300mln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Wabco (WBC) – The co. enters in its first major steering system deal in India. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • BLACKROCK (BLK) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM MARKET PERFORM AT KEEFE BRUYETTE
  • C.H. ROBINSON (CHRW) UPGRADED TO POSITIVE FROM NEUTRAL AT SUSQUEHANNA
  • DIAGEO (DEO) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS
  • HERC HOLDINGS (HRI) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT BUCKINGHAM

  • NEW HOME COMPANY (NWHM) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN
  • ORION ENGINEERED (OEC) DOWNGRADED TO SECTOR WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT KEYBANC
  • PATTERN ENERGY (PEGI) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT BOFA/MERRILL

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump denounces Chequers deal and said a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future trade deal between UK and US
  • Sterling slipping, Dxy rising above 95.000 and equities up approaching week-end
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Uni. of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes, BoE’s Cunliffe, Fed’s Bostic, earnings from Wells Fargo, JP Morgan and Citi

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the upside in Wall St where all majors extended on gains after China’s lack of retaliation and in which tech outperformance pushed the Nasdaq to a fresh record high. This led to a positive open for ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) although the Australia index then floundered amid weakness in its top-weighted financials sector, while the Japanese benchmark sustained its outperformance as exporters cheered a weaker currency and with a surge in Fast Retailing on strong earnings. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) conformed to the predominantly positive risk tone in the region, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) was negative after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations and with some jitters ahead of Chinese Trade Data, although the mainland index has since moved off its lows after the PBoC later announced an MLF operation and after data printed mixed with a larger than expected surplus, which eased some of the data-related fears. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand sapped amid outperformance of riskier assets in Japan, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence for JPY 670bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

 

PBoC refrained from reverse repos, but later announced to lend CNY 188.5bln via 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6727 (Prev. 6.6726)

 

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Jun) 261.9B vs. Exp. 182.5B (Prev. 156.5B).

Chinese Exports (CNY)(Jun) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 4.1% (Prev. 3.2%)

Chinese Imports (CNY)(Jun) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 13.1% (Prev. 15.6%)

China Aggregate Financing (Jun) CNY 1.8trl vs. Exp. CNY 1.4trl

China M2 Money Supply (Jun) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 8.4%

China New Yuan Loans (Jun) CNY 1.84trl vs. Exp. CNY 1.52trl

China's Customs said China trade stability faces challenges from increasing external instability and uncertainty, while it also commented that China will not impose special regulatory measures on US goods nor will it delay US goods at ports. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

US President Trump has warned UK PM May that a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future trade deal between UK and US as they would be dealing with the EU instead of the UK. (Telegraph) This also comes amid reports that UK PM May could suffer the defeat of a crucial Brexit bill as early as Monday after Eurosceptics reacted angrily to the white paper she published yesterday. (Times)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said will sell all his equity holdings and buy US Treasuries. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are largely in the green, with the Euro Stoxx 50 (+0.2%) breaking through its 50DMA in late European trade yesterday and finding support at this level (3,452) this morning. Tech stocks are leading the gains (Infineon +1.7%, Micro Focus +4.3%) and all sectors positive as the positive sentiment from the US continues into European trade.

The IBEX (-0.3%) is once again the only index in the red, and fallen through its 50DMA, with bank stocks extending the losses seen in yesterday’s trade (BBVA -1.2%, Santander -1.1%). The FTSE 100 is outperforming as the GBP is softer.

ThyssenKrupp (-0.6%) have named Guido Kerkhoff as their new CEO

FIXED INCOME

Debt futures have built up a head of steam and sufficient bullish momentum to breach upside levels that were holding firm, with Bunds through 163.00 and Gilts almost reaching 123.50, albeit in relatively thin trading conditions. The precise Eurex and Liffe intraday highs are 163.19 and 123.49, +42 and +34 ticks respectively, and the comparatively low Summer volumes may actually be exacerbating price moves, although the catalyst and impetus for buyers appears to have come from an unlikely or at least indirect source in the form of widespread Usd gains in FX markets. Back to bonds, and from a chart perspective Bunds will be eyeing channel resistance up at 163.40, while Gilts have 123.64 to aim for before 123.88. Turning to US Treasuries, more flattening and knock-on gains in keeping with their EU counterparts.

FX

DXY - The index is back above 95.000 and seemingly heading for strong close to the week, with momentum to challenge the current ytd high (95.531 from June 28) given blanket gains vs G10 peers.

GBP/NZD - An unfortunate, if not unlucky Friday 13th for the Pound and Kiwi thus far, with Cable hit by more negative White Paper headlines amidst reports that US President Trump has delivered a damning verdict via a warning to UK PM May about the ‘soft’ proposal killing prospects of a trade deal between the 2 nations. Market contacts noted stops on a break of 1.3175 after the loss of 1.3200 and there is little in the way of support before the next psychological level at 1.3100 vs a circa 1.3105 low, and ahead of a speech from BoE’s Cunliffe due at 12.30BST. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd has retreated through 0.6750 following a disappointing NZ manufacturing PMI overnight.

EUR - The single currency also a victim of overall Dollar strength, or vice-versa, and looking vulnerable for a deeper pull-back from recent peaks having breached some key chart supports (like the 20 DMA at 1.1654 and a 50% Fib at 1.649 from the 1.1508-1.1790 rally from 2018 low to nearly July peak), with 1.1600 next in sight.

AUD/CAD - The Aud is back below 0.7400 after deriving some relative and temporary support from China’s bigger than expected trade surplus overnight, while the Loonie is back down near 1.3200 vs the Usd and also feeling the weight of another retreat in crude prices.

JPY/CHF - Both extending recent losses vs the Greenback, with BoJ sources suggesting another push-back in inflation target expectations at the end of month policy meeting sparking a further rise in the headline pair through any residual supply at 112.50 to 112.80, and with 113.00 the obvious objective. Similarly, Usd/Chf is grinding higher with no real support for the Franc via a pick-up in Swiss producer/import prices (y/y), and this year’s previous high at 1.0057 now only 5 pips away.

CNH - The off-shore Yuan is back below 4.7000 vs the Usd and levels that prompted intervention not so long ago, both verbal and physical, but no official or unofficial ‘action’ seen so far to leave conspiracy theorists thinking about devaluation in the US-China trade dispute rather than counter import tariff measures.

COMMODITIES

Oil is currently in the red, with Brent -1.0% and WTI -0.3% as we approach the weeks end, and is set for its second consecutive weekly fall. Both measures are finding support at moving average levels, however, with WTI still supported by its 50DMA (USD 69.43/BBL), and Brent finding support at its 100DMA (USD 73.07/BBL) level.

Russian Energy Minister Novak said he is not ruling out an output adjustment depending on other countries or a quick move on >1mln BPD from OPEC+ if needed. He also said he sees Russia's output boost by the end of July at 200k BPD

Gold prices are sliding as the DXY is extending its rally past the 95.000 level. Shanghai steel has hit a 10 month high on the back of low inventories and source reports suggesting the closure of steel mills in China’s largest steel making city, Tangshan, for 5 days amid pollution concerns. Copper is down 0.5% and set for the 5th consecutive weekly fall as US-China trade concerns are weighing on the construction material.

content: A firmer start to Friday’s session for UK debt and STIR contracts amidst more Brexit uncertainty and fall-out from the White Paper that has drawn further criticism before next week’s Parliament vote, and with the EU yet to pass judgement. Gilts kicked off 5 ticks above the previous close at 123.20 and after a brief wobble (123.14 low) have subsequently traded up to 123.27, dragging Bunds up with them to 162.82 (+5 ticks vs -11 ticks at one stage), while the 3 month strip is a tick above parity for the most part. Bonds and 3 month futures eyeing headlines on Brexit, trade wars and CB policy (BoJ sources notably dovish earlier), plus FX developments with the Dollar firmly in the ascendency again.

Bunds: another churn around parity, with a downside bias for choice
content: The 10 year German benchmark remains deeply entrenched within recent ranges, and clearly lacking motivation or rationale for a major break-out in either direction. Indeed, following a modest gap down off the Eurex open and further dip to 162.66, the core debt future has already based and bounced to 162.78 vs Thursday’s 162.77 close before topping out again. In short, rotating and going nowhere fast awaiting something fundamental to really trade off.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the upside in Wall St where all majors extended on gains after China’s lack of retaliation and in which tech outperformance pushed the Nasdaq to a fresh record high. This led to a positive open for ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) although the Australia index then floundered amid weakness in its top-weighted financials sector, while the Japanese benchmark sustained its outperformance as exporters cheered a weaker currency and with a surge in Fast Retailing on strong earnings. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) conformed to the predominantly positive risk tone in the region, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was negative after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations and with some jitters ahead of Chinese Trade Data, although the mainland index has since moved off its lows after the PBoC later announced an MLF operation and after data printed mixed with a larger than expected surplus, which eased some of the data-related fears. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand sapped amid outperformance of riskier assets in Japan, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence for JPY 670bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

FTSE

BT (BT/A LN) – The co. has lost UK broadcasting rights for Serie A matches to rival Eleven Sports. (FT)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – The co. is facing further legal action by its investors, with this threat coming from Quinn Emanuel, who have said that shareholders may be able to seek compensation over losses caused by alleged misleading statements or failures to disclose information. (Times)

Sky (SKY LN) - Co. could be sold for as much as GBP 30bln amid an escalating takeover battle for the European pay-TV group, analysts have predicted. (Times)

BHP Billiton (BLT LN) – The union for Chile’s Escondida mine has said the wage offer is unacceptable and has said strike action is on the cards if no changes are made. (Newswires)

UK Property Names – The value of the UK property market has fallen by ~ GBP 27bln since the start of the year, as according to Zoopla, with Brexit to blame. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES 

Ryanair (RYA LN) – The co. cancelled 30 flights on Thursday amid failed union talks. (Sky News)

BROKER MOVES

IMI (IMI LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

DAX

Allianz (ALV GY) – CEO is planning to present a new strategy for the co. in late November. He also said they are not looking to get rid of their German life insurance portfolio. (Handelsblatt)

Linde (LIN GY) – The co. and Praxair are set to win antitrust approval for their merger, as according to sources. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – North Rhine-Westphalia’s Premier has backed the co.’s chairman in opposing a breakup of the co. following the resignation of their CEO. The Premier of the co.’s home-base has said he wants “long-term development, not short term profits”. (Newswires)

Metro (B4B GY) – German union Verdi have called for 34k workers at Metro’s Real hypermarkets to strike on Friday in protest over a wage agreement. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Vinci (DG FP) – Airport units reports Q2 traffic +7.4% y/y. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Elisa (ELISA FH) – Q2 revenue EUR 458mln vs. Exp. EUR 456mln, pre tax profit EUR 95mln vs. Exp. EUR 92.5mln, EBITDA EUR 160mln vs. Exp. EUR 157mln, 2018 revenue expected to be at same level or higher than in 2017. (Newswires)

SMI

Barry Callebaut (BARN SW) – 9 month sales volume +6.9% vs. Exp. +6.9%, sales revenue CHF 5.2bln vs. Exp. CHF 5.25bln, confirm mid-term targets. Say they are growing faster than the market despite sales volume growing more slowly in the quarter. (Newswires)

Gjensidige (GFJ NO) – Q2 earned premiums NOK 5.99bln vs. Exp. NOK 6.02bln and profit before tax of NOK 1.25bln vs. Exp. NOK 1.46bln. (Newswires)

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the upside in Wall St

    US President Trump has warned UK PM May that a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future trade deal between UK and US

    Looking ahead, highlights include Uni. of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes, BoE’s Cunliffe, Fed’s Bostic, earnings from Wells Fargo, JP Morgan and Citi

    ASIA

    Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the upside in Wall St where all majors extended on gains after China’s lack of retaliation and in which tech outperformance pushed the Nasdaq to a fresh record high. This led to a positive open for ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) although the Australia index then floundered amid weakness in its top-weighted financials sector, while the Japanese benchmark sustained its outperformance as exporters cheered a weaker currency and with a surge in Fast Retailing on strong earnings. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) conformed to the predominantly positive risk tone in the region, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was negative after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations and with some jitters ahead of Chinese Trade Data, although the mainland index has since moved off its lows after the PBoC later announced an MLF operation and after data printed mixed with a larger than expected surplus, which eased some of the data-related fears. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand sapped amid outperformance of riskier assets in Japan, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence for JPY 670bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.
     

    PBoC refrained from reverse repos, but later announced to lend CNY 188.5bln via 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)
    PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6727 (Prev. 6.6726)
     

    Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Jun) 261.9B vs. Exp. 182.5B (Prev. 156.5B).
    Chinese Exports (CNY)(Jun) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 4.1% (Prev. 3.2%)
    Chinese Imports (CNY)(Jun) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 13.1% (Prev. 15.6%)

    Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Jun) 41.6B vs. Exp. 27.2B (Prev. 24.9B).

    Chinese Exports (USD)(Jun) Y/Y 11.3% vs. Exp. 9.5% (Prev. 12.6%)
    Chinese Imports (USD)(Jun) Y/Y 14.1% vs. Exp. 21.3% (Prev. 26.0%)

    China's Customs said China trade stability faces challenges from increasing external instability and uncertainty, while it also commented that China will not impose special regulatory measures on US goods nor will it delay US goods at ports. (Newswires)

    UK/EU

    US President Trump has warned UK PM May that a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future trade deal between UK and US as they would be dealing with the EU instead of the UK. (Telegraph) This also comes amid reports that UK PM May could suffer the defeat of a crucial Brexit bill as early as Monday after Eurosceptics reacted angrily to the white paper she published yesterday. (Times)

    French finance minister Le Maire said if the US trade war persists, EU will take new decisions and commented that specific deal on autos with the US threatens jobs. (Newswires)

    FX

    FX markets remained uneventful during Asia-Pac trade with the DXY flat but in proximity to retest the 95.00 level to the upside, while EUR/USD consolidated at yesterday’s levels below 1.1700 and GBP/USD mildly underperformed after reports that US President Trump is said to warn UK PM May a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future UK-US trade deal. Elsewhere. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were underpinned by the risk appetite, which also helped high-beta currencies hold on to recent gains.

    COMMODITIES

    WTI crude futures were relatively unmoved alongside quiet overnight trade across commodities and ahead of the contract rollover this weekend, although prices are back above USD 70/bbl after having briefly slipped below it on Thursday in a mild extension of the aggressive pullback seen mid-week. Elsewhere, gold was slightly dampened and the greenback held steadfast and copper traded flat as the mostly positive risk tone provided a base for prices.

    CME raised RBOB gasoline futures margins to USD 4000 per contract from USD 3450 per contract for August. (Newswires)

    US

    The treasury complex moved sideways on Thursday. The yield curve modestly bear-flattened with most of the yields higher by under 2bps. Major curve spreads saw another session of flattening by c.1bps; 2s10s fell to as low as 25bps for another fresh low, while 2s30s and 5s30s also narrowed by 2bps and 1bps respectively. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settled 3 ticks lower at 120-05.

    Fed’s Powell (Chair, Neutral) reiterated the Fed is hearing concerns regarding trade wars and that sustained high tariffs could be a negative for the economy. Furthermore, Powell said low wage growth is a puzzle, but added the labour market is strong by any measure and the US economy is in a really good place. (Marketplace)

    Fed’s Harker (Non-Voter, Dove) stated he welcomes 4 rate hikes this year if inflation accelerates, but added he still sees 3 hikes this year and that Fed rate hikes could lift policy rate to 3.00%-3.25%. Furthermore, Harker said inflation is moving towards the 2% target, while he also noted the inflation goal is symmetric and he would be comfortable for inflation to move to 2.5%. (Newswires)

    US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said many of the US trade talks with China have broken down. (Newswires)

    US Commerce Secretary Ross said will sell all his equity holdings and buy US Treasuries. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly positive following Wall St's gains and Nasdaq's fresh records; while region also eyes Chinese trade data
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as region takes impetus from the upside in Wall St where all majors extended on gains after China’s lack of retaliation and in which the Nasdaq posted a record high on tech outperformance. This led to a positive open for ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) although the Australia index then floundered amid weakness in its top-weighted financials sector, while the Japanese benchmark sustained its outperformance as exporters cheer a weaker currency and with Fast Retailing surging on strong earnings. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) is negative after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations but instead later announced to lend though its Medium-term Lending Facility and with Chinese Trade Data eyed, while Hang Seng (+0.4%) conforms to the predominantly positive tone across the rest of the regional bourses.

FX markets continue to lack any major drivers for Asia-Pac trade with the DXY flat but in proximity to retest the 95.00 level to the upside, while EUR/USD consolidates at yesterday’s levels below 1.1700 and GBP/USD slightly underperforms after reports that US President Trump is said to warn UK PM May a soft Brexit would probably kill a potential future UK-US trade deal as they would be dealing with the EU instead of the UK. Elsewhere. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses remain underpinned by the risk appetite, which has also helped high-beta currencies hold on to recent gains.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with demand sapped amid outperformance of riskier assets in Japan, although downside is also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence for JPY 670bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

SOEs
- China centrally-owned SOEs' profits rose 26.4% Y/Y in June and rose 23% Y/Y to CNY 887.8bln during H1. (newswires)

Other News
- Chinese Commerce Ministry stated that so far they have had no contact with the US about restarting negotiations. (Newswires)
- US President Trump said that US is in a nasty trade battle with China but added they will negotiate a fair trade deal if that's possible and that he expects something very good with China in the end. (Newswires)
- US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said many of the US trade talks with China have broken down, while he earlier commented that the US is available to discuss with China to the extent that the country wants to make changes on trade and that the US is very focused on retaliatory trade measures and how to resolve them.
